title.narrative: Urban Legislation Knowledge Sharing To Support Nua Implementation (Urban Lex)

description.narrative:
The purpose of this project is to strengthen the role of urban legislation in the Latin American and Caribbean region through knowledge-sharing to support the Implementation of the New Urban Agenda. This project is an opportunity to further understand the regional actors, network and thematic at hand to be able to support the implementation of the Regional NUA plan as part of an extension of the previous project on urban knowledge.
UrbanLex is a free online global ‘library’ of the legal instruments that govern urban development. The database features seven critical areas of urban law that are essential to the sustainability and development of urban areas. Under each legal area the user will find a catalogue of laws from a wide range of countries from all regions. The aim of UrbanLex is to be more advanced than a simple data repository, while still being easy for non-experts to use. A principal element of UrbanLex’s value is in the digests that accompany each law, providing an accessible description of its key contents and objectives. The laws can be searched by region, country, theme, and keywords.
The seven critical areas of urban law featured on the database include:
? Taxation, Finance Economic Development
? Governance and Government
? Infrastructure and Basic Services
? Urban Planning
? Disaster Recovery and Urban Resilience
? Building and Construction
? Land and Environment
Beneath the digest a link to an external website or document that is relevant to the law is also provided. The purpose of the link is to provide the user with an opportunity to learn more about the law and what kind of effects it may have. Many of the external links will lead to information provided by our partners who specialize in the relevant legal area and expose the user to research institutions in countries all over the world.
The reality is that researchers and urban stakeholders do not have the time or resources to find and compile urban laws. As a result, a knowledge gap has formed around urban legislation, especially in developing countries where governments do not make all laws, and particularly secondary regulations and local law, available online. This gap is obstructing research efforts and limiting the capacity to develop solutions. Urban residents and planners watch development take place in their cities and towns without any adherence to the legal framework, partly because of the limited access to the laws that shape that framework. UrbanLex provides a central source of information that not only fills this knowledge gap but also makes research and comparative analysis easy.
The New Urban Agenda (NUA) emphasizes the importance of collaborating with international and regional organizations and agencies, including within the United Nations system and with multilateral environmental agreements, development partners, international and multilateral financial institutions, regional development banks, the private sector and other stakeholders, to improve the coordination of their urban and rural development strategies and programs to implement an integrated approach to sustainable urbanization, incorporating the implementation of the New Urban Agenda.
It also reaffirms the need to improve United Nations system-wide coordination and coherence in the area of sustainable urban development by promoting exchanges of best-practices to capture and share the lessons learned and the potential for knowledge transfer. The Agenda recommends expanding regional and international North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation opportunities, as well as subnational, decentralized and city-to-city (peer) cooperation to contribute to sustainable urban development, develop Capacities and promote exchanges of urban solutions and mutual learning at all levels and to all relevant actors.
In this regard, it is essential to reaffirm the importance of sharing good and best practices in transferring knowledge and methodologies, as well as the results obtained, to other authorities or local organizations struggling to find solutions to address similar problems. While in different contexts, urban centers face similar problems to meet the rights of their inhabitants. Therefore, the systematization and transfer of knowledge, whether in a database or using the resources of a network of experts, is a great opportunity to seek concrete solutions and technical capacity to promote sustainable urban development.
LAC and urban legislation
Latin America is the most urbanized region in the world, with more than 80% of its population living in cities. This urban growth took place in the last forty years (1950-1990) due to a massive migration, commonly referred to as the "urban explosion". The rate of urban growth has declined significantly and yielded a second urban transition, which deals with the failures and problems resulting from this accelerated growth. Therefore, it is the right moment to focus efforts on promoting sustainable urban development.
As a middle-income region characterized by widespread inequality, Latin America and the Caribbean exhibit different levels of development and knowledge. Its current status represents an achievement, where several outstanding practices have resulted in surprisingly positive results, but also a permanent challenge, which has not guaranteed sustained and inclusive results for all.
This context has produced an exceptional range of urban practices. The numerous contrasts, great achievements and continuous bottlenecks offer a rich laboratory for the exchange with the countries of the region and around the world. While cities have their specificities, there are similarities with other regions of the world, and much can be learned from the experience of Latin America and the direction it is taking.
The recognition of Latin American and Caribbean practices at the Dubai International Award for Best Practices demonstrates the richness of projects and initiatives in the region. Since 1996, LAC comprises about 40% of all practices received twice a year, and have also received better and state award winners. Other awards also spearheaded by the ROLAC office, such as the Inspiring Practice open-call in 2016 that received 146 projects submitted from 16 countries, showed an encouraging number of projects still in the implementation phase already putting in practice various concepts of sustainable urban development.
The Inspiring Practices Open-call for the New Urban Agenda aimed to launch a cycle of knowledge management to support the implementation of this New Agenda. The idea was to take advantage of the capillarity of regional networks to give the opportunity to more projects to participate, to be recognized, to learn and to teach. This initiative has been co-organized with Flacma, the Ibero-American and Caribbean Forum on Best Practices and Mercociudades.
The projects received reaffirm the innovative nature of the region on its path towards integrated development. All the projects underwent a thorough evaluation by a technical committee where they were evaluated based on pre-established criteria in the bases of the call.
The four finalist projects stood out for providing an integrated view of urban development, demonstrating tangible results and tackling the cross-cutting agenda items on climate change, gender, human rights and youth.
Out of the 146 practices, 86 projects submitted a relevant response on urban legislation, yet the answers were still vague and many times did not connect the project with local and national laws. Urban legislation was often not seen as part of the sustainability of the project. This shows a gap in understanding the importance of legislation in sustainable urban development. Without effective urban law, urban development interventions are one-off projects. With it, they become long term programmes that can be used by citizens and investors to plan for the future. There can be no sustainable development without good laws.
This provides an opportunity to strengthen the understanding and connection between the projects and legislation in the region. It can also provide great input for further research that can shape local laws, considering different complexity, density and diversity of urban life. This project approach is partnership-driven, and supports comparative analysis with real-time relevance.
Thus, the project will work with its current networks such as the Iberoamerican and the Caribbean Forum of Best Practices, the Urban Legislation partners in the region and the other partners mentioned from the open-call. This project will also aim to increase geographic coverage in the region, especially to include the Caribbean.
